document.text: zon. And, in looking straight up at the Northern Cross, Vega will be seen about one-fourth of the way toward the horizon dug west. Further, the Little Dipper will be seen almost midway between the Northern Cross and the Big Dipper, that is, in the middle north western sky. An interesting star in the Sep tember sky is Altair. Altair will be found about one-third of the dis tance to the southern horizon from the Northern Cross. It is a bright star and one of our closest neigh bors. It is not a large star, but it is bright because it is so close only fifeen light years away.

document.text: Zeppelins Built Since the War. According to a dispatch from Berne, Switzerland, there are now some eighty Zeppelins in the German service. This statement is said to be based on information developed at Friedricbshafen, where the airship works are located. Recently one of the latest type Zeppelins made a trial flight. 1 bore the number LZ-95, and in design varied considerably from the ante-bellum Zeppelins. Its gondolas are said to be of plated steel. The craft is plentifully supplied with ma chine guns and apparatus for throw ing bombs and aerial torpedoes among tho latter being a new typo which is reported to be far more pow erful then any heretofore developed. In fact, rumor has it that the new i aerial torpedo is to play a prominent part in the event of the German war ships and Zeppelins coming out from their sheltering harbors and engaging in battle with the British fleet in the North sea.Scientific American.

document.text: Zedekiah was made king of Judah by the king of Babylon 2417, but in spite of this kindness and the word of the Lord spoken to him by Jeremiah Jer. 3817, 18 cf. Jer. 523, he re belled against the king of Babylon. He relied upon the help of Egypt, but all that Egypt could do was to cause temporary interruption of the siege of Jerusalem. I. The Seige of Jerusalem vv. 1-3. 1. Time of vv. 1, 2. It began on the tenth day of the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiahs reign and -lasted about eighteen months. The tenth month according to the Jewish calendar corresponds to our December- January, as their calendar year began about the middle of March. The reason the exact time is given is that this was to be an event of great importance to the Jews in their exile. 2. The Method v. 1. Nebuchadnez zar came in person with a large army and encamped against Jerusalem and built forts against it round about. It is thought that siege walls were built, around the city, shotting it in. On the tops Of these walls forts were built from which missiles of destruction could be hurled by their engines of war against the city. With the city shut in its fall was only a question of time. 3. The Famine v. 3. Gelkie says It was speedily followed, as is always the case, with an outbreak of pesti lence. Food was well-nigh gone. There had long been no bread. Moth ers were at last driven to murder and eat their children. Tlie richest citi zens wandering about searching for scraps in the dunghills. Even outside the city the people were starving. There was no bread for the people of the land. It is estimated that one- third of the people of Jerusalem died of starvation. II. Zedekiahs Flight and Fate vv. 4-7. 1. The City was Broken Up v. 4. The Chaldeans had succeeded in mak ing an opening in the wall so large that they could make their way into the. city in spite of all that the He brews could do. Resistance was car ried on to the bitter end. 2. Zedekiahs Flight v. 4. The king with his men of war fled by night to ward the plain. His object, no doubt, was to cross the Jordan at Jericho and hide in the mountains east of Jordan. 3. Zedekiahs Fate vv. 5-7. 1 He was overtaken in the plains of Jericho v. 5. When his flight was. discovered the Chaldean army pursued and cap tured him. 2 He was brought to the king of Babylon at Riblah v. 6. Riblah was a town north of Damascus. It was the kings headquarters from which he directed his armies against Tyre and Jerusalem. Before Neb uchadnezzar, Zedekiah was tried as a criminal. 3 His.fate v. 7. His sons were slain in his sight his eyes were put out he was bound with fet ters of brass and they carried him to Babylon where he remained pris oner until the day of his death Jer. 5211. III. Jerusalem Destroyed vv. 8-10. The dismantling of the city was de layed a month, perhaps awaiting in structions from Nebuchadnezzar, who was at Riblah. 1. They Burnt the House of the Lord v. 9. This was the sacred temple built by Solomon with additions and modifications. Before burning it they plundered it of all its sacred contents. 2. Burnt the Kings House v. 9. This was doubtless the palace built by Solomon. 3. Burnt All the Houses of Jeru salem v. 9. The implication is that the common houses were left for he people v. 12. 4. They Broke Down the Walls of Jerusalem. The aim was to render the walls useless as a means of de fense. IV. The Disposition of tho People vv. 11, 12. 1. Carried Them Into Captivity v. 11. The people who were left In the city and those who had deserted to the Babylonians were carried to Baby lon all such as would be of use in Babylon. 2. The Poorest of the Land Were Left v. 12. The people who would not likely make any trouble were left as vine-dressers and husbandmen Doubtless they were looking forward to colonization by foreign peoples. The object in leaving these people was that the country might be ready for their coming. Over these people Gedaliah was appointed as governor, with head quarters at Mizpah.

document.text: ywshington.Immediate steps to Reestablish the value of farm products Raa parity with those of other com- aiodtties was asked of Congres and president Harding by the National Agricultural Conference through the Ittnanimous adoption of a resolution to that effect. The resolution was con- Itaiued in a report from the marketing committee and members said Its adop tion meant that something must be done by the President and Congress Itatnedlately. The resolution follows! -H Is the sense of this committee  that the Congress and the President of the United States should take such rte as will immediately re- establish a fair exchange value for ill farm products with that of all other  commodities. The conference at the same time rejected a resolution of the National Farmers Union, offered by J. S. Wan- Ihamaker, of South Carolina, which would have called for a Government minimum price guarantiee on farm products. Some measure of stabilization of prices was advocated by J. M. Ander- rson of St. Paul, Minn., who said some such step should be taken until Eu- frooe is restored economically. He favored participation of the United States in European readjustments, hut said We dont want to embarrass the President by asking more entangle- ments In foreign affairs. E. B. Page, of North Dakota, asked I for a minimum guarantee ou wheat for I two years. The conference previously had  adopted a resolution which read With respect to the question Of I Governmental price guarantees, we. feerthat there should be a compre hensive study of this subject. There fore, we urge that the Congress cause j a careful investigation of this whole I problem to be made by some proper authority which will report its find ings as early as practicable. Co-operation of farm marketing was j also recommended and indorsed.  Commendation of the agricultural bloc in Congress was voted unani- ! mously by the Conference through un animous adoption of the report of the ! committee on agriculture and price relations.  The committee also recommended and the conference adapted resolu tions urging the Government to use Its offices to aid in the economic ré habilitai ion of Europe and expressing the belief that such steps should be taken as necessary to limit acreage of particular crops to balance produc tion and restore the farmers dollar to Its normal purchasing .power. Other resolution reported by the committee which were adopted includ ed approval of the program of the American Arms Conference delegation, commended the investigation by the Dwart.ments of Commerce and Justice of retail prices, urged mofe vigorous action in the placing of agriculture on parity with other industries, advocated the gathering and distributing of foreign markets end production re- ports by the Department of Agricul ture and urged investigation by Con gress of plans to stabilize the dollar And equal tariff protection.

document.text: Youth Exchange program is getting into full swing. By the end of next week four foreign visitors will begin an ex tended stay on Virginia farms. They are Miss Margaret Martin, North ern Ireland, who arrived on Friday, August 20 Seppo Olavi Kanervisto, Finland, due Friday, August 27 Fer nando Bozo Vargas, Costa Rica, and Miss Elizabeth Aebi, both scheduled to arrive Thursday, September 2. All of them will stay until early October. Returned last week from Costa Rica was Dominic Lay, Fair fax 4-Her. Scheduled to leave Vir ginia September 11, also under the IFYE program, is Miss Edith Frame, of Quinton, who will go to New Zealand.

document.text: Young W omans Slayer Himself Fired At, He Says. F ort W orth, Tex. Special.-Miss Lula W illiams, aged 25 years, daugh ter of T. L. W illiams, a prosperous farm er, living six miles north of Ar lington, was shot and killed by R. H Bates, aged 40, a farm er, in front of Bates home. Bates stated he was called to the door and after a pistol shot had been fired at him, he seized a shotgun and fired into the dark ness. There was no outcry although he discerned a fleeing figure. An hour later the woman was found dead In front of the gate. She was dressed in a m ans overcoat and cap. Bates is under arrest.

document.text: Youll find out fer yerself, mister, he answered sullenly, an maybe damn quick too. They are in the grape arbor to the south of the house, broke ln Eric. That was where Fa gin told them to lie quiet and wait orders. Then we will explore along the north side, keeping the fence between us. Ive got a handful of men over there ln the orchard. If you are both ready well go. I took a look myself at TomB rope- tying, and found It satisfactory. In deed, in remembrance of my own suf fering, l even loosened the strain a little, cohfldent the fellow could never free hlmBelf unaided. Then the three of us, Mortimer armed with his late guards gun, crawled up over the edge of the bank, raq without stopping across the open space, and crouched ln the shadow of the fence, tt was still dark, although a faint gray tinged the eastern sky-line, barely perceptible through the Intervening trees. The great house, a hundred yards away, was but a blurred outline, distinguish able by the lights shining out through open windows. At that distance no sound reached us. However, If Mor timer was right, the way would be clear for. our passage along the front, under shelter of the fence, even though ,a sentry was posted there, and we could creep up to the walls on the opposite side unobserved. All we needed to do wsb to advance With caution. Whispering directions Into the ears of the others, I move 4 for ward slowly, Mortimer close to my shoulder. I could see across the top rail of the fence, and the open space beyond yielded no point of conceal ment Tell me the rest of your story, I said, speaking softly, as we go along. Where did Fa gin take you? To a sand cave we rode a night and a day to get there. Treat you all right? Well as he could, I suppose. I had enough to eat, but was guarded close ly, and the fellows were a bit rough. Did you gain no Inkling of what they were up to? No tiie men I saw knew nothing, or pretended not to. I only saw Fagin twice. Once he came to assure him self that I was really myBelf. Some-

document.text: You trade at a Southern shoe store. You give the dealer your money. You probably buy a western or northern made shoe. When the dealer pays his bill, thfe money, less a small per cent to the dealer, goes north or west and the South is that much poorer. Keep your money at home. Let it work for better times, better wages, more factories, more work for Southern people.

Week, probably I should choose the more northern route, around Scot land, and then skirt tho Norway coast through the North sea. To place me on some other vessel at sea would spoil your plan, Mr. Hol lis? It would render our chances of suc cess much less. The only possibility would be tlie meeting of some Ameri can ship, homeward bound, whose cap tain would promise to make no report. Such a one might be hard to find, espe cially if ho suspected we were endeav oring to carry munitions of war to Ger many.  Do you believe the Germans nre right in this warthat you ought to aid them? ,I cannot answer that, I answered honestly enough, for I do not fully understand the conditions. To be per fectly frank, however, my sympathies are with England and France. In this case I am not considering either side, but the poor devil who owns this ship and cargo. What we carry on board here will not be a drop In the bucket, but lts loss will spell ruin to him, and that Is the thought which In fluences me. And I could not even dispatch a messagewireless ? The Indian Chief has no equipment. No, Miss Vera, we shall bo absolutely lost to the world until we are either captured, br safe In some German port. I would not deceive youthe project Is both a desperate and a dangerous one., jT   The girl remained silent, her eyes lowered to the deck. I had said all possible, determined as I was not to Influence her decision. As she did not speak, or change her attitude, I arose nnd walked across the cabin to where I could look out forward. Mr. Hollis. Yes. I turned. I must decide this? You mean to leave It all to me?- There Is no other way. But I do not know what to say.

document.text: You ask me whats my hobby? My hobby, sir, is ham. You ask me if Im serious. I tell you sir, I am. These verses by a bard of Bun combe County, whose name escapes us at the moment, incorporate a lot of truth. The man with a ham hobby is serious about it. He will argue for his particular kind of ham, even if he hasnt tasted it in years, with all comers and at all hours. People will argue about many things, such as how mint julips ought to be made, but no people argue more than those about how true and proper hams -ought to be cured. There is a story that a North Carolinian, a Virginian, a Tennes sean and a South Carolinian Dr. R. G. Coker of Chapel Hill, so the story goes were arguing about how long it should take to cure a ham. Con noisseurs from the first three states were making the time longer, and until they came to Dr. Coker and asked him How long do you take to cure a ham in South Carolina? I dont know, said Dr. Coker. You dont? came the chorus. No, he said, in .South Carolina we inherit our hams. We have about quit selling the good, old ones in North Carolina, so we reckon it is about time for us to start inheriting them. In Georgia, however, they have a apeed-up process. document.text: York, Pa., Special.Part of through train for the West which left Baltimore over the Northern Central Railway at 9 oclock was blown from the tracks by a big charge of dynamite soon after leaving this city at 10.44 P- M. The train was composed of four Pull man cars, a day coach, a combination car and express car. It was running at the rate of 45 miles an hour, when the engine struck the dynamite. Al though the windows in the locomotive cab were blown to pieces, Engineer Thurmer stuck to his post and succeed ed in stopping the heavy train after it had run over the ties for 200 feet. The scene of the wreck is about one mile north of the city, close to where Codorus creek flows between high hills The Northern Central crosses the stream on an open iron bridge, which is 50 feet above the bed of the stream. Conductor Grove says the bandits evi dently planned to throw the train into the creek. When the attempt failed the robbers we believe, took refuge in the hills.

document.text: YNCUBURO. V Takes Lot to Sink One Of Uncle Sams Ships WASHINGTON.A torpedo from a U-boat clipped off the stern of the destroyer escort Fogg, but her crew got her safely to a friendly port 400 miles away. The action occurred last Decem ber 20 north of the Azores in the Atlantic, but the navy withheld the story until recently. The Fogg has been repaired and is ready to fight again. The torpedo ripped into the ship just aft of the deckhouse when she turned to give assistance to a dis abled landing ship in a convoy. The explosion hurled the Foggs fantail into the air and the entire stern sec tion began to settle. Within minutes, a third of the ship was flooded. A bulkhead athwart- ships kept her afloat, however, until the remaining two-thirds of the ship could be made watertight. Finally, the entire stern section sheared off. The remainder of the ship re gained buoyancy and another vessel took the Fogg in tow. A jury rud der was rigged up, the ship was bal lasted, and eventually the Fogg was taken in tow and returned to the United States.

document.text: YIELDS OF CREEPING ALFALFA VARIETIES LOWER THAN RECOMMENDED TYPES Creeping alfalfa varieties, which have spurred many questions from farmers the past few years, can be expected to yield 25 to 50 percent lower than recommended  varieties in Virginia. This is indicated by Virginia tests and reports from other states. VPI agronomists say In addition to having low yields, these varieties are very susceptible to leaf spot and other diseases common to the east ern part of the United States. It is hard in most cases to maintain a satisfactory stand under Virginias humid conditions, and there is no indication to date in the east that creeping alfalfa is any more suitable for grazing than standard varieties. Two creeping alfalfa varieties, Nomad and Rhizoma, have received the .most attention publicity-wise, and seed of each is available. Both were developed in the Pacific North west Oregon and Canada in semi- arid areas where natural fertility and lime conditions are most favor able for alfalfa without the addition of lime and potash as fertilizer.

document.text: Yesterday mornings fight? asked De Spain reluctantly. Yes, sir. How did he happen to catch us ou El Capitan? He saw a fire on Music mountain and watched the lower end of the gap all night. Sassoon was a wide-awake man.  Well, Pm sorry, Pardaloe, con tinued De Spain after a moment No body could call It my faul. It was either he or Ior the life of a woman who never harmed a hair of his head, and a woman Tm bound to protect. He was running- when he was hit. If he had got to cover again there was noth ing to stop him from picking both of us off. He was hit ln the head. De Spain was silent. It was a soft-nose bullet contin ued Pardaloe. Again there was a pause. HPU tell you about th at too, Pardaloe, Do Spain went on collectedly. I lost my rifle before that man opened fire on us. Nan happened to have her rifle with herIf she hadnt hed ve dropped one or both of us off El Capi tan. We were pinned against the wall Uke a couple of targets. If there were soft-nose bullets ln her rifle Its be cause she uses them on gamebobcats and mountain Ilona. I never thought of it till this minute. That Is It What I came up to fell you has to do with Dave Sassoon. From what happened today ln the gap I thought you ought to know It now. Gale and Duke quarreled yesterday over the way things turned out they were pretty bitter. This afternoon Gale took It up again with his uncle, and It ended ln Dukes driving him clean out of the gap. Where has he gone? Nobody knows yet. Ed WIckwire told me once that your father was shot from ambush u good mnny years ng6. It was north of Medicine Bend, on a ranch near the Peace river that you never found out who killed him, and that one reason why you came up Into this country was to keep an eye out for a clue. What nbout It? asked De Spain, his tone hardening. I was riding home one night about a month ago from Oalabasas with Sas soon. Hed been drinking. I let him do the talking. He began cussing you out, and talked pretty hard about what youd done, and what hed done, and what he was going to do Nothing, It seemed, would hurry the story. Finally, Sassoon says That hound dont know yet who got his dad. It was Duke Morgan thats who got him. I was with Duke when he turned the trick. We rode down to De Spains ranch one night to look up a rustler. That, concluded Pardaloe, was all Sassoon would say. He stopped. II seemed to wnlt. There was no word of answer, none of comment from the man sitting near him. But, for one, at least, who heard the passionless, monotonous recital of a murder of the long ago, there fol lowed a silence as relentless as fate, a silence shrouded ln the mystery of the darkness and striking despair Into two heartsa silence more fearful than any word. Pardaloe shuffled his feet. He coughed, but he evoked no response, I thought you was entitled to know, he said finally. Now that Sassoon will never talk any more. De Spain moistened his lips. When he spoke his voice was cracked and harsh, as It with what he had heard he had suddenly grown old. You are right, Pardaloe. I thank you. Iwhen Iln the morning. Par daloe, for the present, go back to the gap. I will talk with WIckwireto morrow.  Good night, Mr. de Spain. Good night, Pardaloe. Bending forward, Ump, ln his chair, supporting his head vacantly on his hands, trying to think and fearing to think, De Spain heard Pardaloes meas ured tread on the descending steps, and listened mechanically to the re treating echoes of his footsteps down the shaded street. Minute after min ute passed. De Spain made no move. A step so light that It could only have been the step of a delicate girlhood, a step free as the footfall of youth, poised as the tread of womanhood and beauty, came down the stairs. Slight as she was, and silent as he was, she walked straight to him ln the dark ness, and, sinking between his feet, wound her hands through his two arms. I heard everything, Henry, she murmured, looking up. An Invol untary start of protest was his only response. I was afraid of a plot against you. I stayed at the hend of the stairs. Henry, I told you long ago some dreadful thing would come be tween ussomething not our fault. And now It comes to dash our cup of happiness when It Is filling. She stopped, hoping perhaps lie would sny some little word, that lie would even pat her head, or press her hand, but he sat Uke one stunned. If It could have been anything but this! she pleaded, low and sorrowfully. Oh, why did you not listen to me before we were engulfed! My dear Henry! You whove given me all the happiness I have ever hadthat the blood of my own should come against you and yours! The emotion she struggled with, and fought back with all tho strength of her nature,- rose ln a re sistless tide that swept her on, ln the face of.Jds ominous silence, to despair. Her breath, no longer controlled, came brokenly, and her voice trembled. You have been very kind to me, Henryyouve been the only man Ive ever known that always, everywhere, thought of me first I told you I didnt deserve It, I wasnt worthy of It His hands slipped silently over her hands. He gathered her close Into his arms, and hts tears fell on her up turned face. TO BE CONTINUED.

document.text: Yesterday a west bound freight train put out a fire which burned over about 1000 acres of land on the north side of the road between this point and Evergreen. A barn was burned on the farm cf Mrs. S. H. Kelley. Several small houses were also burned and it is said one cow  perished in the flames. Tbe same engine set fire to a shed at this place in the Smith block, and but for the timely discovery v. ould have resulted in a serious conflagration.

document.text: Yes, tor some people ln this world there seems no let-up. They are pursued from youth to manhood, and from manhoodto old age. Very distinguished are Lord Staf fords hoUnus, the Earl ot Yarboroughs honnds, and Qaeen Victoria pays eight thousand live hundred dollars per year to her Master Ot Backhonnds. But all of them put together do not equal in number or speed, or power to hunt down, the great kennel ot hounds ot which Sin and Trouble are owner and master. Bnt what Is a relief forall this pursuit ot trouble, and annoyance, and pain, and be reavement? My text gives It to you In a word of three letters, bat each letter is a harlot if you would triumph, or a tbron If yon want to be orownod, or a lake It yon would slake yonr thirstyes, a chain ot three lakesO-O-D, tbe One for whom David longed, and the One whom David found. Up to Tuesday night there were 40 cases and 8 deaths. There are three cases in the town of Phoebus, between the home and Old Point. The hotels at Old Point are deserted, and most of the gariison at Fort Monroe has been sent to the north. Strict quarantine has been established, and it is hoped that the disease can be kept from spreading. There i no good reason for a panic.

document.text: Yakalos, New Steel Breed, May Solve Meat Problem Wainwright, Alta.When the world hangs ont the Standing Room Only sign the problem of meat supply may be solved by a new breed of live stock called yakalos being devel oped In the national park at Waln- wrtght by crossing the bnffalóes with yaks Yakalos combine thè meat-pro ducing qualities of the yak with the foraging characteristics of the buffalo according to G. B. Botimeli, director of the animal hqsbandry division of the Department of Agriculture. The new animals breed true to type, he said, and have proved more adaptable than cattalo evolved several years ago by crossing buffalo with domes tic cattle. The meat of yakalos is said to ha almost Identical with beef aside from being finer grained. The animals are hardy, can forage for themselves, ara capabla of wintering In the open, and are resistant to many of toe common diseases of domestic tetti. Buffalo In the government herd at Wain wright park have Increased so rapidly that 2,000 young animals were shipped north last spring to a wild bison preserve-on the Slave river. The herd at Walnwright, which Is the cen ter of a fertile farming area, now numbers 8 . 000 ,

Baird, of Louisiana, died in Washington from a complication of di- eases. The remains were taken to Bastrop, La., for interment. In addition to the family the following named Senators and Representatives accom panied tbe remaihs Senators Cuffrey, of Louisiana, and Bacon, of Georgia Repre sentatives Meyer and Davey, of Louisiana Bartlett, of Georgia Morris, Eddy and Me- Cfeary, of Minnesota Marsh, of Illinois Gibson and Brownlow, of Tennessee Cum mings, of New York, and Ciayton, Under wood and Bankhead, of Alabama, who will act as honorary pall-bearers. Samuel T. Baird was well-known In north ern Louisiana, where for seventeen years he has been a prominent factor at tbe bar, on the bench aud in politics. He was a native of that State and was thirty-eight years old. Born at Oak Ridge on May 6 , 1861, his prim ary instructions were begun very early aud he received uls education both at home aud at Vincenues, Ind. In 1870 he commenced the study of law, and three years later was admitted to the bar. Iu 1884 he was elected district attorney of the sixth judicial circuit, served in this capacity for four years, and then vacated it to become district judge for the same district. He occupied this bench for four years and then relinquished it to resume his private practice. In April, 1896, he was elected to tbe State Senate. He was a delegate to the national Democratic con vention in Chicago in 1896. Mr. Baird bad just finished his first term in tbe House of Representatives and had been re-eiocted to the fifty-sixth Coogresj.

document.text: WythevilleDexter Goad, clerk of the Carroll County Court, where Judge Massie and four other persons were killed by the Allen clansmen on March-14, was the principal witness Saturday at the trial of Floyd Allen on the charge of murdering Common wealths Attorney William M. Foster. Mr. Goad was wounded four times in the affray with the Allens, and bullets from his revolver broke Floyd Allens leg, and also injured Sidna Allen. The witness was asked why he was armed with two pistols on the day of the affray. Counsel for jthe defense ob jected, on the ground that testimony elicited by this question would he hear-say or a mere expression oi opinion. After brief argument by Mr. Draper, for the state, and Mr. Willis, for the defense, the question was with drawn. On recross-examination by Judge Hairston, for the defense, Mr. Goad said that after the shooting he step ped into the clerks office and reloaded his automatic pistol, but made no at tempt to use it again. This pistol shoots eight or nine times with one loading. The next witness was J. M. Beville, 66 years old, wearing a checked jump er under his coat and striped trousers, and with long iron gray chin whiskers. He lives two miles from Floyd Allen. He has been friendly with him. He met Floyd Allen on the road between their two houses some time before the trial. Allen said he was sorry he had got into the trouble with the boys he wished he had just let the boys go to jail. Now he was in it, he would submit to anything they put on him In the way of fine, but if they tried to put him in the penitentiary he would make a hole in the courthouse, and if Judge Bolen his counsel didnt do his duty he would be plied up with the rest of them. Witness said Mr. Allen, I hope you wont get into no such a thing as that. Cross-ex amined by Mr. Willis, the witness said he had often borrowed money from Floyd Allen, but always paid him. He denied that Floyd Allen holds a note of his for borrowed money. Judge Bolen Testifies. Judge Bolen, of Carroll, was put on the stand and he practically confirm ed Bevilles account of his transactions with Floyd Allen, showing that it is a matter of 9, involving some ques tions over a sale of land for parti tion. Sidney Spraker, 22 years old, a well- dressed young farmer, said he lived near Hillsville and works for Mr. Wil kinson. He was in the courtroom at Hillsville the day before the shooting, when the jury in Floyd Allens trial was out and was expected to return. Floyd Allen came to the stove, on the north side of the room, where witness was, as if to warm himself. Claude Allen walked up to Floyd, reached out and took hold of his hand and said Let me feel your pulse, old man. After about three seconds Claude dropped Floyds hand and said Its heating regular. Floyd Allen asked, in a sort of whisper Are all the hoys ready? Witness did not hear the reply. Floyd then walked across to near the door of the judges room and stood on a bench. W. D. Tompkins, a well-known law yer of the Carroll bar, another eyd wit ness, was next examined. His office is directly across the street from the courthouse. He did not know the ver dict in the Allen case had been given and went into court to attend to legal business. He exchanged a few words on a matter with the judge, then con ferred briefly with Mr. Tipton, also of the local bar, and handed him a paper on which to indorse an excep tion. Witness stepped outside the bar, and, facing Mr. Tipton and the Judge, waited for the indorsement. He then noticed that th- courtroom was very quiet and that here was an air of sup pressed excitement. He inquired and was told that the verdict was what it was. The witness said The First Shots. About that time Judge Massie asked Judge Bolen if anything more was to be done in the Allen case that day. Judge Bolen said No, and added that Floyd Allen wanted to speak to one of his sons. Claude Allen was called and went to the bar, where he

document.text: WTH THE FIRST MARINE AIRCRAFT WING IN KOREAThe infantry has confirmed that Marine F irst Lieutenant Jam es McCleery destroyed four enemy tanks with one napalm bomb. He had to. It was the only weapon he had left. Lieutenant M cCleery of St. Louis, Mo., and his wingm ate from the M arine  D evilcat squadron, F irst Lieutenant Loren W. Calhoun of Ashton, 111., were near the end of an arm ed search over North Ko- rea when they spotted the Commu nist tanks. The M arines had used up all their bombs, rockets and machine gun ammunition. They carried one napalm fire bomb as their only weapon. Flying extrem ely low, Lieutenant McCleery discovered the four cleverly camouflaged tanks pro truding from a natural revetm ent under an overhanging hill. This was a larger order than he had figured on, but he decided to m ake the napalm bomb do as much dam age as possible. He set his Corsair fighter-bomber into a dive and released the napalm tank. It landed right in the middle of the target and splattered its fire over the four tanks. When the pilot left the area, all the tanks were burning. Two days later, an infantry unit moved north through the area and sent word back that all four tank w ere burned out and destroyed.

document.text: Wsldersee Fitting Ont Another Pnnlttve Ex pedition-French Troops to Stay. London By Cable. Dr. Morrison, wiring to the Times yom Pekin, says The German staff have notified the al lies of their intention to send another expedition to suppress Boxers in the southern part of the province of Chili, beyong Chingching, and have invited he co-operation of the allies. The de parture of the French troops has been countermanded. - The British military authorities are extending the railroads to Tungchow, along the Peiho. This will greatly fa cilitate the withdrawal of the foreign troops, and, commercially, will cause important developments in the north after the work of pacification is com pleted. The German War Office has received a dispatch from Pekin concerning the explosion at the arsenal at Kalgan, and naming Lieut. Kummer as the officer wounded. The dispatch characterizes the explosion as very serious, saying seven cavalrymen are reparted missing or found dead, and that three men, be side Lieut Kummer, were seriously wounded. The viceroy of Canton has signed a contract for the removal of the Macao barrier in the Canton river, constructed during the Franco-Chinese war, which has been a great obstacle to navigation. The viceroy has also squelched the na tive opposition to the construction of new wharves, pointing out that they are necessary to the interests of the trade. The viceroys action is creating a good impression.

document.text: Wrong Train Rldo Cautot Airman Action on Front PHILADELPHIACpl. J o h n J. Murphy, Jr., 20, wrote his parents here about a wrong train ride that caused him to see front line action in Keora92 days worth. Murphy wrote that he fell asleep on a train while enroute back to his air-terminal group headquarters and woke up north of the 38th parallel. Calvary officers refused to believe his story and he wound up in bat tle, a rifle in his hands. He took part in 13 patrols and won the Combat Infantrymans Badge before being returned to his outfit, which had listed him A.W.O.L.

document.text: write the peace. Every day more and more American food stuffs have to be transported to our fighting men and our Allies. The Nazis have overrun and pillaged Russias fertile granary in the Ukraine . They stripped North Africa bare . . . Japanese hordes have burned and blasted the good earth of valiant China . . . England has already increased her tillable acreage fifty per cent, and plans to increase it another ten per cent this year. But even that is not enough to feed the brave people of the tight little island, who fought off our foes single-handed in 1941. And there are our own millions of war workers who must be fed.

document.text: Wreek of tha Chilian Steamer Tucapel Near Qullca. Lima, Peru.A telegram received here from the purser of the Chilian steamer Tucapel, which was wrecked near Qullca, says that the total num ber of persons drowned was 32. Ninety others were saved. Those who lost their lives were the captain of the vessel, the first and second officers, 20 members of the crew and nine deck passengers. The Tucapel during a heavy fog struck on an unchartered stretch of rocks 20 miles north of Qullca, which lies several hundred miles south ot Lima.

document.text: Wrecked By Spreading Rolls. Altamont, Mo., Special. The Chi cago, Rock Island and Pacific railway, which left Kansas City for the north was wrecked by spreading rails two miles east of here. Two persons were probably fatally hurt and fifteen oth ers seriously injured. The train, which was made up of baggage, smoker, two chairs, a Pullman sleeper and an ob servation car, was running at the rate of only fifteen miles an hour when the accident occurred. The baggage car, smoker and one chair car were turned over and went down the embankment.

Eugene Wood Kinston sportsman, would have -tliR general assembly of North Carolino spend 10,000 to buy 10,000 goats and turn them loose in the eastern and western part Of the state In the hope that the number would Increase to 100,IKK In ten years. He believes, does Mr. Wood, that the goats would Rid the state oT weeds and under growth and thus.beautify woods, and natural parks. Eradicate snakes and other pests by eating up weeds and things that snakes lurk In. Give the mosquito population a wallop by eating weeds In mnrshes and allowing the sun to dry up the water puddles, V And, another thing, they would provide a new. supply of game, he says, adding. document.text: WOULD be difficult to estimate how greatly Americas high standard of health is directly due to our dairy farmers end milk distributors. For milk is more lavishly available to more families in America, and at lower cost, than in any other country, It is the best milk in the world, and abundant supply plus our system of low-cost distribution, create a standard which is a model for the world. One out of every 15 U. S. families is dependent on milk for a livelihood, and 1949 cash farm income from milk, in Virginia, West Virginia and North Carolina alone, totalled 122,162,000.
